titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Lucy Kramer Cohen Papers
titlestmt.author: by Jennifer Meehan and Jonathan Harmon

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday March 27, 2019 at 03:07

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Lucy Kramer Cohen papers document her decades-long career in the federal government, including her contributions to The Handbook of Federal Indian Law and her work on the staff of Representative Helen Gahagan Douglas and for the War Labor Board and the Public Health Service, as well as her various professional activities and affiliations as an anthropologist and later as an artist, including her work with the artist and sculptor Pietro Lazzari. The collection consists largely of professional correspondence and memoranda, reports and analyses for various government agencies and projects, conference proceedings, printed material stemming from Kramer Cohen's government employment and organizational affiliations, manuscripts for Felix S. Cohen's The Legal Conscience, which she edited, and various employment papers, including applications, wage records, CV drafts, and employer recommendations. Also found are personal and family papers, which include correspondence between and received by Kramer Cohen and Felix S. Cohen, clippings of obituaries, material relating to the memorial service for Felix S. Cohen, legal and financial documents relating to Kramer Cohen's father's estate and affairs, and property records. Other papers of Felix S. Cohen include research material, clippings, and correspondence relating to Puerto Rico and the Spanish Civil War. Audiovisual materials include a film and reel-to-reel recordings of of Felix Cohen and audiodiscs of his memorial service.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Karen Holmes and Gene Tweraser, 2009, 2014.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Lucy Kramer Cohen Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Lucy Kramer Cohen Papers. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received a preliminary level of processing at the time of acquisition, including rehousing in acid-free boxes and folders. Material in the collection has yet to be organized. Folder titles appearing in the contents list were transcribed from original folders, but have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles were supplied by staff during preliminary processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Felix S. Cohen Papers (WA MSS S-1325). Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.
Felix S. Cohen Papers Addition (WA MSS S-2602). Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

bioghist.head: Lucy Kramer Cohen (1907-2007)
bioghist.p: Lucy Kramer Cohen was born in Brooklyn, New York, graduated from Barnard College in 1928, and earned her Master's degree in 1929 in mathematics and anthropology at Columbia University. She married Felix S. Cohen, a lawyer, in 1931, and they had two daughters, Karen and Gene. Kramer Cohen worked as an unpaid assistant with her husband in the United States Department of the Interior, helping to draft the Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 and The Handbook of Federal Indian Law in 1942. She was on the staff of Representative Helen Gahagan Douglas (D-Calif.) during Douglas's three terms in the House from 1944 to 1950. Kramer Cohen also worked for the War Labor Board, the Office of Price Administration, the State Department and the Public Health Service, where she wrote and edited reports in its office of data analysis and management. She also did research work for anthropologists in Washington in between her government jobs, and did researching and writing for Interior Secretary Harold Ickes. She collected, edited, and published her husband's work as The Legal Conscience (New Haven, Yale University Press: 1960) after his death in 1953. She served on the board of directors of the Association on American Indian Affairs from 1961 to 1994. Kramer Cohen officially retired from the federal government in 1977, but continued to work on contract until her actual retirement in 1989. In her later years, she took up drawing and painting, and served as editor of the Washington Watercolor Association newsletter. She died of a stroke in 2007.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Lucy Kramer Cohen papers document her decades-long career in the federal government, including her contributions to The Handbook of Federal Indian Law and her work on the staff of Representative Helen Gahagan Douglas and for the War Labor Board and the Public Health Service. They also document her various professional activities and affiliations as an anthropologist and later as an artist, including her work with the Association on American Indian Affairs and with the artist and sculptor Pietro Lazzari. The collection consists largely of professional correspondence and memoranda, reports and analysis for various government agencies and projects, conference proceedings, printed material stemming from Kramer Cohen's government employment and organizational affiliations, manuscripts for Felix S. Cohen's The Legal Conscience , which she edited, and various employment papers, including applications, wage records, CV drafts, and employer recommendations. Also present are personal and family papers, which include correspondence between and received by Kramer Cohen and Felix S. Cohen, clippings of obituaries, material relating to the memorial service for Felix S. Cohen, legal and financial documents relating to Kramer Cohen's father's estate and affairs, and property records. Other papers of Felix S. Cohen include research material, clippings, and correspondence relating to Puerto Rico and the Spanish Civil War. Audiovisual materials include a film and reel-to-reel recordings of of Felix Cohen and audiodiscs of his memorial service.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two groupings: November 2009 Acquisition; and June 2014 Acquisition.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 49-56 (audiovisual materials): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This accession is roughly organized into four groupings: correspondence, awards and certifications, photographs, and audiovisual materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes holiday cards from colleages and friends from Yale.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
